answers.answer: Given your history you are at severe risk of loss of vision, poor vision and even blindness even if you do not have a child. You should be doing everything you can to keep your sight. That means keeping your A1c test well below 7.0, keeping your blood pressure and cholesterol very low, making sure you weight in average or below average for you height and age, NOT smoking, eat a good diet and pray.You will need to discuss the risks with your retina physician Eye MD ophthalmologist. I would say they are considerable. Adopting is a safer alternative.JCH III MD

question: I am 30 years old and have had Type 1 diabetes for 23 years. I have a 2 year old boy. After pregnancy I developed severe proliferative retinopathy in both eyes. They have both had extensive laser work performed on each. My vision is slowly improving. I am having less bleeds. However, the laser has caused traction and I am now required to have vitrectomy surgery.My main concern is whether or not i can have another child. Doctor, would you recommned that a diabetic patient who has existing retinopathy to have a baby? What could I be risking? I know pregnancy hormones can progress retinopathy but at what stage do things settle.
title: Diabetic retinopathy and pregnancy
